filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

desc.objtitle: The Soldiers Casting Lots for Christ's Garment, Object 1 (Butlin 495)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work with his monogram and dated it just left of center and just above the bottom margin. The inscription lower right below the image is also in his hand. See the textual transcription.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design takes its subject from John 19:23-24. In the foreground is a group of seven armored male soldiers. The leftmost soldier kneels or crouches, facing right and down. He bends forward or hunches over slightly. His legs are bent underneath him and he wears a sandal on his right foot. He wears a chestplate, but has a cloth shirt and breeches or pants on as well. He has short, slightly curly hair and may be smiling. His right arm is raised horizontally and he may have just thrown the dice with his right hand. His left arm is bent slightly upward, palm out, and he points upward with his left hand. The second-to-left figure has short, curly hair and faces forward and down, bending forward slightly. He may look down or his eyes may be closed. His mouth may be slightly open. His left arm is bent, with his left hand held vertical, palm out. The third-to-left soldier has slightly curly hair and sits, facing left and bending forward slightly to look down. His mouth is partly open. He wears a short-sleeved shirt under his armor. His left leg is extended forward and his left arm is raised horizontally, resting on the table in front of him. His right arm is bent, palm vertical. The solider far right stands, facing left and bending forward to look down. He wears a helmet and holds a halberd (a battle ax with a long handle) that he leans on. He also wears a short-sleeved shirt under his armor and a sandal on his left foot. His right leg is bent, and his left arm is bent upward. There may be a cloth draped over his right wrist. A soldier behind the right-most figure in the group faces left and bends forward to look down so that his face is not visible. He may lean on a halberd that he holds. He wears a cape over his armor. Just above the dice player third from the left sits a soldier, facing left and down. His face is not visible, but he is presumably looking at the dice. He wears a braided hat on his head. Below the chest of the right-most soldier is another soldier visible only as an armored head, facing right and down, with his mouth open. He is presumably looking at the dice as well. Above the group of soldiers on the right are two halberds in addition to the two evidently held by the soldiers. All four halberds probably have wooden handles, like spears. In the middle of the group of soldiers in the foreground is a table or slab of rock covered by a cloth, on which the soldiers throw dice. In the left foreground of the design is what appears to be a sandal. To the left of the leftmost soldier in the foreground are twenty round shapes that may be rocks, bags, or roughly sketched heads that are meant to suggest a crowd. In the middle ground of the design is a mound or low hill, on which stand three wooden crosses. This is Calvary, where Christ was crucified. On the left cross in the is visible a nude body, facing away and to the right. This figure is hanging with its arms raised at 135 degrees. This is one of the thieves crucified with Christ. On the middle cross two nude arms raised at 135 degrees are visible, with the figure facing away. This is Christ. In the middle ground on the rightmost cross a nude figure of the second thief is visible, hanging while facing away and to the left. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees. To the left of the leftmost cross stands a figure, facing away and to the right. Its gender is indeterminable, but it wears a long gown and has long hair. Between the leftmost and middle cross in the middle ground stand five figures. The leftmost figure is just visible as a head with long hair, facing right. The second-to-left figure is of indeterminable gender, but may be female. She(?) faces right and wears a gown, as well as has long hair. The middle figure of this group is that of an old man with long hair and a beard, facing forward and to the right, while looking up. He may wear a gown. The second-to-right figure is that of a female, probably the Virgin Mary or one of the other Marys at the crucifixion, facing forward and right, and looking up. She wears a veil over her hair and has a long gown. The rightmost figure is just suggested as the back of a head, facing right and perhaps away. Between the central and rightmost cross in the middle ground stands a group of at least seven figures. The leftmost figure has long hair and a gown, and may be facing away. The second-to-left figure is that of a gowned female with long hair, who faces left and down. Her left arm is bent upward and she may hold her hand to her face. Her mouth may be open. This may be one of the Marys present at the crucifixion. The third-to-left figure may be that of a male with long hair, facing forward and looking up and to the left. The middle figure of this group may be that of a gowned female with long hair, facing away and to the left. Her left arm may be bent upward. She may be one of the Marys present at the crucifixion. The third-to-right figure of this group may be that of a male with a beard, facing forward and looking up and to the left. The second-to-right figure is that of a gowned female with long hair, who faces away but looks forward and up to the left. Her mouth is open. She may have a hood on her gown. She may be one of the Marys at the crucifixion. The rightmost figure is just visible as a head with long hair, facing to the left or possibly away. It may be gowned. There might be another figure to the right, only hinted at. In the background is a group of buildings. To the left is a tower with an archway and portcullis. A stone(?) wall supports a group of figures. Above the wall rises what appears to be a Gothic(?) building with spires and arches. A crowd of at least eighteen figures, visible only as roughly sketched outlines of heads and upper bodies, stands on the wall in the background. These figures face forward, with the leftmost group facing slightly right and the rightmost group facing slightly left. They may be looking at the crucified figures. This scene appears to take place at night and is dark. The sky is cloudy with a pink wash that may suggest sunrise or sunset. A glow in the sky around the middle cross may suggest the sun, or be an aura emanating from Christ.
